usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of audit logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda API calls (e.g., CreateFunction, UpdateFunctionCode, InvokeFunction) arenâ€™t captured by CloudTrail or centralized logging, unauthorized or malicious activity goes unrecorded.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Malicious insiders or compromised roles making API calls
  • Automated tools invoking or updating functions without generating logs
  • Misconfigured CloudTrail trails or logâ€‘delivery failures

Impacts

  • Undetected Changes: Function code or configuration modifications arenâ€™t noticed
  • Forensic Blind Spots: Incidents canâ€™t be reconstructed or attributed
  • Compliance Failures: Violation of auditâ€‘logging mandates (e.g., PCIâ€¯DSS, HIPAA)

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker updates a paymentâ€‘processing Lambda to include malicious logic; without CloudTrail logs, the change isnâ€™t traced.
  2. A rogue script purges function versions via the SDK; absent audit entries, the deletions go unnoticed until failures occur.
  3. CloudTrail misconfiguration drops InvokeFunction records; a compromised role invokes backdoor functions repeatedly without alerting security teams.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Bootstrap backdoor persistence in custom runtimes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Custom runtimes in AWS Lambda rely on a 'bootstrap' file as their entry point, executed before reaching the handler. Without proper monitoring, this file can be manipulated to include malicious logic, enabling persistence across deployments.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers with access to deployment processes can modify the 'bootstrap' file to execute unauthorized activities, such as exfiltrating data, establishing backdoors, or altering runtime functionality.
Impacts
The compromise of the 'bootstrap' file can lead to unauthorized data access, persistent backdoors in the runtime environment, and stealthy modifications that evade detection during typical security reviews.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker with deployment privileges embeds malicious code into the 'bootstrap' file that exfiltrates sensitive data to an external server. Despite subsequent changes to the main handler logic, the hidden backdoor remains operational, continuing its activity undetected across multiple deployments.

reference.name: Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat â€” When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor (July 11, 2025)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1494 - Runtime Data Manipulation

threat.name: Code integrity compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Malicious alteration of Lambda function code or its dependenciesâ€”via compromised build pipelines, direct edits, or tainted layersâ€”injects unauthorized logic into your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD systems, supplyâ€‘chain attackers
  • Vectors: Backdoored build artifacts, console/API code edits, inclusion of malicious Lambda layers

Impacts

  • Unauthorized code execution under your functionâ€™s IAM role
  • Data exfiltration or tampering of event payloads and backend resources
  • Lateral movement via calls to other AWS services
  • Reputational harm and remediation costs

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CI/CD Injection: An attacker hijacks the build server to insert a reverseâ€‘shell payload into the deployment ZIP.
  2. Console Swap: A compromised admin replaces production handler code via the AWS Console, embedding dataâ€‘exfiltration logic.
  3. Malicious Layer: A popular thirdâ€‘party layer bundles a cryptoâ€‘miner, which executes under your account when included.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Singleâ€‘AZ failure for VPC functions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions are placed in a VPC that spans only a single Availability Zone, an AZ outage (due to hardware failure, networking issues, or scheduled maintenance) renders those functions unable to access their ENIs, subnets, or dependent servicesâ€”causing complete service disruption.

Threat Agentsâ€¯/ Attack Vectors

  • AWS Infrastructure Failures: Power, network, or hardware faults isolated to one AZ.
  • Misconfiguration: VPC subnet or NAT gateway deployment limited to a single AZ.
  • Capacity Events: AZâ€‘specific resource exhaustion (e.g., ENI limits reached) preventing new function attachments.

Impacts

  • Service Outage: Affected Lambdas cannot execute, disrupting APIs, event processing, or backâ€‘end jobs.
  • Data Delays: Queues and streams back up, leading to timeâ€‘sensitive data loss or processing lag.
  • Operational Costs: Emergency redeployments or crossâ€‘AZ workarounds consume engineering time and may incur extra charges.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. AZ Hardware Failure: A hardware fault knocks out networking in AZâ€¯A; all Lambda functions in that singleâ€‘AZ VPC lose ENI attachment and fail to process inbound events.
  2. NAT Gateway Capacity Spike: A DDoS flood targets the NAT gateway in the lone AZ, saturating its throughput; VPCâ€‘bound Lambdas canâ€™t reach the internet for API calls.
  3. Planned AZ Maintenance: AWS schedules maintenance that briefly disables ENI provisioning in AZâ€¯B; because all subnets reside there, no new Lambda invocations succeed until maintenance completes.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Outdated runtime environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Outdated runtime environments occur when Lambda functions continue using deprecated or unpatched language runtimes (e.g. old Node.js, Python, Java versions), missing security fixes and performance improvements.

Threat Agentsâ€¯/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers scanning for known CVEs, supplyâ€‘chain adversaries embedding exploits in dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting publicly documented vulnerabilities in EOL runtimes.
    • Injecting malicious payloads through outdated library transitive dependencies.
    • Leveraging insecure default configurations tied to legacy runtimes.

Impacts

  • Remote Code Execution: Attackers exploit CVEs to run arbitrary code in your functions.
  • Data Breach: Compromised functions expose sensitive input or environment data.
  • Service Disruption: Unpatched bugs cause function crashes or performance failures.
  • Compliance Risks: Use of unsupported runtimes may violate organizational or regulatory policies.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CVE Exploit: A function running Pythonâ€¯2.7 is targeted with a known bufferâ€‘overflow exploit, allowing an attacker to execute shell commands.
  2. Dependency Hijack: An outdated Node.js runtime pulls in a vulnerable version of a logging library; an attacker injects malicious code via crafted log messages.
  3. Misconfiguration Crash: A Javaâ€¯8 function uses an old JDBC driver with memoryâ€‘leak bugs, causing repeated OOM errors and denial of service under load.

threat.name: Overly broad IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly broad IAM permissions occur when AWS Lambda execution roles or associated policies grant more privileges than necessaryâ€”often using wildcards for actions or resourcesâ€”exposing your functions to escalate privileges or access unrelated services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised deployment pipelines, and external attackers using stolen credentials.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • IAM policies with "Action": "lambda:*" or "*" on "Resource": "*" attached to function roles.
    • Overâ€‘permissive trust relationships allowing any principal to assume the Lambda role.
    • Failure to apply leastâ€‘privilege when granting access to AWS services (S3, DynamoDB, IAM).

Impacts

  • Privilege Escalation: Functions can call APIs beyond their scope (e.g., creating or deleting roles).
  • Data Breach: Exfiltration of sensitive data from S3 buckets, databases, or Secrets Manager.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised functions pivot to other services or resources in your account.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended changes to infrastructure, such as spinning up expensive resources or deleting critical stacks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. S3 Overreach: A Lambda role with s3:* on * is compromised; the attacker lists and downloads all buckets, harvesting PII.
  2. IAM Role Abuse: An overly broad iam:* permission lets a malicious function create a new admin user, granting full account control.
  3. Cost Shock: A function granted ec2:RunInstances and ec2:TerminateInstances is hijacked to spin up large fleets of instances, incurring massive charges and then deleting them to cover tracks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Credential compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Credential compromise in AWS Lambda occurs when the secrets, API keys, or IAM credentials used by functions are exposed or stolenâ€”either through code, environment variables, or execution contextâ€”allowing attackers to impersonate or control your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, automated bots, thirdâ€‘party library leaks, compromised CI/CD pipelines
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Embedding secrets (AWS keys, database passwords) in function code or plaintext environment variables
    • Retrieving IAM role tokens from the Lambda execution environment via SSRF or metadataâ€‘endpoint exploits
    • Exposing credentials in version control systems, build artifacts, or CloudWatch logs

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Function Invocation: Attackers invoke functions at will, potentially incurring costs or executing unwanted actions
  • Privilege Escalation & Lateral Movement: Stolen credentials grant access to other AWS services or higherâ€‘privilege roles
  • Data Exfiltration & Tampering: Sensitive data processed by Lambdas (e.g., PII, business logic) can be read or modified
  • Service Disruption & Financial Loss: Illicit use of credentials can flood queues, trigger throttling, or bill for large-scale invocations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hardâ€‘coded Key Leak: A developer commits a Lambda function with embedded AWS keys to GitHub. An attacker clones the repo, uses the keys to read S3 buckets, and exfiltrates customer data.
  2. Metadata Endpoint Abuse: A malicious library loaded into the Lambda execution environment makes HTTP calls to the IMDS endpoint, harvesting the functionâ€™s IAM role token and using it to spin up new EC2 instances.
  3. Log Exposure: A misconfigured logging library prints database credentials from environment variables to CloudWatch Logs; a compromised IAM principal with logs:GetLogEvents reads the logs and uses the credentials to drop the database.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1550.001 - Application Access Token

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Lack of network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions share flat or overly permissive network configurationsâ€”such as residing in default VPC subnets without segmentation or securityâ€group restrictionsâ€”they gain unfettered access to internal systems and the internet, increasing risk of lateral movement and data exfiltration.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Compromised function code, malicious insiders, or thirdâ€‘party dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting broad VPC subnet placement to reach databases, caches, or internal APIs.
    • Using SSRF or openâ€redirect flaws within the function to pivot across network boundaries.
    • Leveraging unrestricted egress to exfiltrate data to attackerâ€‘controlled endpoints.

Impacts

  • Lateral Movement: Attackers breach internal resources (e.g., RDS, Redis) via the compromised functionâ€™s network path.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive payloads or environment variables are sent out over the internet.
  • Service Compromise: Unauthorized access to microservices, service meshes, or backâ€‘end systems, undermining confidentiality and integrity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Database Pivot: A stolen function token is used to invoke a Lambda in the default VPC, which then connects to an internal MySQL cluster on portâ€¯3306 to dump data.
  2. Internal Reconnaissance: An attacker injects SSRF payloads into a function endpoint, causing it to scan internal HTTP management interfaces and map out privileged services.
  3. Covert Exfiltration: A compromised dependency causes the function to upload decrypted S3 objects to an attackerâ€™s external SFTP server, bypassing network ACLs.

threat.name: Lack of resource tagging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without consistent tagging, Lambda functions canâ€™t be programmatically identified for ownership, environment, or purposeâ€”hindering cost tracking, security policy enforcement, and operational oversight.

Threat Agentsâ€¯/ Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators, uncontrolled automation, and rogue deployments.
  • Vectors:
    • CI/CD pipelines creating functions without required Environment or Owner tags.
    • Manual console creations that omit security or compliance tags.
    • Thirdâ€‘party tooling that doesnâ€™t enforce tagging standards.

Impacts

  • Visibility Gaps: Security teams canâ€™t quickly locate or audit sensitive functions.
  • Policy Evasion: Tagâ€‘based IAM or GuardDuty suppression rules fail to apply, allowing unauthorized access.
  • Cost Overruns: Untracked â€œorphanâ€ functions incur unexpected charges.
  • Cleanup Challenges: Hard to identify and decommission unused or outdated functions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hidden Malicious Function: An attacker deploys a backdoor Lambda without Team or Project tagsâ€”escaping routine audits and persisting undetected.
  2. Policy Bypass: A compromised automation role creates a function lacking the Compliance=PCI tag, sidestepping strict IAM permissions tied to that tag.
  3. Orphaned Resources: A deprecated serviceâ€™s Lambdas remain untagged; months later, they still run and bill but arenâ€™t owned or monitored by any team.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data exposure at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data exposure at rest in AWS Lambda occurs when sensitive informationâ€”such as environment variables, function code packages, layers, or log snapshotsâ€”is stored unencrypted or with weak key management, making it accessible to unauthorized parties if storage systems are compromised.

Threat Agentsâ€¯/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised AWS credentials, and thirdâ€‘party service breaches.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Retrieving unencrypted Lambda environment variables or code bundles from S3/ECR.
    • Accessing /tmp storage on compromised execution hosts.
    • Downloading unencrypted CloudWatch log exports or Lambda layer artifacts.

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Exposed API keys, database passwords, or tokens.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of atâ€‘rest encryption mandates (PCIâ€¯DSS, HIPAA, GDPR).
  • Lateral Movement: Harvested credentials enable access to other AWS resources.
  • Reputational & Financial Damage: Data breach remediation costs and loss of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. ECR Artifact Theft: An attacker with ECR read permissions pulls a Lambda image containing hardâ€‘coded secrets in its code, extracting them offline.
  2. S3 Snapshot Breach: Misconfigured S3 bucket hosts unencrypted function packages; adversaries download and inspect code to harvest environment variables.
  3. Log Export Exposure: A support engineer exports CloudWatch logs (including sensitive payloads) to an unencrypted S3 bucket, which is later accessed by unauthorized users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data interception in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data interception in transit occurs when communication to or from Lambda functionsâ€”such as API Gateway requests, serviceâ€‘toâ€‘service calls, or event payloadsâ€”is sent without proper TLS or through misconfigured network paths, allowing adversaries to eavesdrop on or alter the data stream.

Threat Agentsâ€¯/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Network eavesdroppers, manâ€‘inâ€‘theâ€‘middle attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Invoking Lambda over HTTP (API Gateway or Function URL) instead of HTTPS
    • Misconfigured VPC endpoints or transit gateways that donâ€™t enforce encryption
    • Disabling or improperly validating TLS in SDKs or custom HTTP clients

Impacts

  • Credential Theft: API keys, JWTs, or signed URLs in request headers can be captured
  • Payload Exposure: Sensitive event data (PII, business logic) is readable in flight
  • Message Tampering: Inâ€‘transit modification of inputs or outputs leads to corrupted processing
  • Replay Attacks: Captured invocations can be resent to trigger unauthorized function executions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. API Gateway Misuse: A functionâ€™s URL endpoint is configured for HTTP only. An attacker on the same network sniffs request bodies containing user credentials and session tokens.
  2. VPC Endpoint Bypass: Lambda communicates with an internal service through a VPC endpoint that doesnâ€™t require TLS. A compromised EC2 instance in the VPC intercepts and logs unencrypted RPC calls.
  3. TLS Downgrade in SDK: A custom Python client disables certificate verification when calling a Lambda-backed API; an attacker performs a MITM attack to inject malicious payloads into the functionâ€™s execution.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

threat.name: Unauthorized invocation via public resource policies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly permissive Lambda resource policies (e.g. "Principal": "*") expose functions to anyone on the internet or any AWS account, allowing unauthorized parties to invoke them without credentials.

Threat Agentsâ€¯/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised thirdâ€‘party accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Resourceâ€‘based policies granting lambda:InvokeFunction to Principal: "*".
    • Crossâ€‘account policies missing Condition: {"StringEquals": {"AWS:SourceAccount": ...}}.
    • Automated scanners discovering public ARNs and issuing invoke requests.

Impacts

  • Unauthenticated Execution: Attackers trigger functions at will, potentially running malicious logic.
  • Cost Overruns: Highâ€‘volume invocations rack up unexpected AWS charges.
  • Data Exposure & Tampering: Functions that read or write sensitive data can be abused to leak or corrupt information.
  • Downstream Disruption: Flooded event sources (queues, streams) or dependent services may be overwhelmed or fail.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Function Flood: An attacker discovers a public Lambda ARN and scripts thousands of InvokeFunction calls per minute, incurring heavy costs and throttling backend resources.
  2. Crossâ€‘Account Abuse: A partnerâ€™s account has open invocation rights; a malicious actor uses it to invoke a paymentâ€‘processing Lambda with crafted payloads, creating fraudulent transactions.
  3. Data Leak via Unauthorized Payloads: A function tied to an S3 bucket runs on every invocation; by invoking it with custom payloads, an attacker tricks it into returning sensitive file contents in its response.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption and restrict access to parameters
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure all parameters in AWS Parameter Store are encrypted using AWS Key Management Service (KMS). Use customer-managed KMS keys instead of default AWS-managed keys for enhanced control and granularity over access permissions. Apply fine-grained IAM policies to restrict access to parameters based on the principle of least privilege. Audit and monitor access to sensitive parameters using AWS CloudTrail logs. Regularly review access permissions and rotate encryption keys as part of your security maintenance practices.

References

  1. AWS Parameter Store Best Practices

reference.name: AWS Security Best Practices for SSM Parameter Store

countermeasure.name: Implement API security controls with proper authorization checks
countermeasure.desc:
Configure API security controls in AWS Parameter Store to enforce strict authorization checks for all API requests. Use AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies to define fine-grained permissions for accessing, creating, updating, or deleting parameters. Ensure that all API requests are authenticated and that only authorized users or roles can perform specific actions. Utilize resource-based policies to restrict access to sensitive parameters and enable logging of API activities using AWS CloudTrail to detect unauthorized access attempts.

References

  1. IAM Best Practices for AWS Parameter Store
  2. AWS API Security Guidelines

reference.name: AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting and monitoring for parameter access
countermeasure.desc:
Set up rate limiting for parameter access in AWS Parameter Store to prevent abuse and ensure system stability. Use AWS Service Quotas to configure and monitor API request limits for accessing parameters. Implement CloudWatch Alarms to track access patterns and detect anomalies, such as spikes in requests, which could indicate misuse or malicious activity. Combine monitoring with AWS CloudTrail to log and analyze parameter access events, ensuring compliance and timely detection of potential threats.

References

  1. AWS Service Quotas Documentation

reference.name: AWS CloudWatch for Monitoring AWS Systems Manager

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events

countermeasure.name: Restrict IAM roles and implement least privilege
countermeasure.desc:
Define and apply restrictive IAM roles for AWS Parameter Store to ensure access is granted based on the principle of least privilege. Assign permissions that are specific to the actions required by each role, such as read-only access for viewing parameters or write access for updates. Avoid using wildcard permissions (e.g., ssm:*) and explicitly specify allowed actions and resources. Regularly review and audit IAM policies to revoke unnecessary privileges and ensure roles are aligned with operational needs.

References

  1. IAM Best Practices for AWS Parameter Store

countermeasure.name: Use encryption for all data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all data transmitted to and from AWS Parameter Store is encrypted to protect it from interception or tampering. Use HTTPS endpoints to enforce TLS 1.2 or higher for secure communication. Configure applications and services accessing Parameter Store to verify the validity of TLS certificates. Avoid using plaintext protocols or unencrypted connections, even within internal networks. Regularly monitor and update TLS configurations to align with the latest security standards.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: An attacker triggers denial of service by overloading parameter retrieval requests
threat.desc:
General threat description

High volume of requests to AWS Parameter Store can overload the system, causing slow responses or service outages.
Threat agents/Attack vectors

Malicious users sending excessive requests to overload the service.
Impacts

Denial of service for applications relying on AWS Parameter Store.
Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker launches a flood of API requests to retrieve parameters, causing legitimate users to experience service interruptions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: An attacker exploits IAM role misconfiguration to gain unauthorized access to parameters
threat.desc:
General threat description

Poorly configured IAM roles can allow attackers to assume roles and access sensitive information within the AWS Parameter Store.
Threat agents/Attack vectors

Attackers may use social engineering or brute force to obtain access to IAM roles.
Impacts

Unauthorized access to sensitive application settings, credentials, or database connection strings.
Example Attack Scenarios

A developer configures an IAM role with broad permissions, allowing unintended access to sensitive parameters.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure parameter transmission over the network
threat.desc:
General threat description

Parameters sent over an unencrypted connection can be intercepted by attackers, exposing sensitive data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors

Man-in-the-middle attacks on network traffic.
Impacts

Exposure of credentials or configuration details during transmission.
Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker intercepts unencrypted traffic from an application retrieving sensitive parameters from AWS Parameter Store, leading to unauthorized access.

threat.name: An attacker accesses unencrypted parameters due to misconfigured access policies
threat.desc:
General threat description

An attacker could access sensitive, unencrypted parameters if access control policies are misconfigured. Parameters stored without encryption are vulnerable to unauthorized access.
Threat agents/Attack vectors

Attackers or unauthorized users gaining access via improperly configured IAM roles or policies.
Impacts

Exposed sensitive data such as API keys, passwords, or database credentials.
Example Attack Scenarios

An application inadvertently uses an overly permissive policy for Parameter Store, allowing an unauthorized user to read unencrypted configuration values.

threat.name: A misconfigured parameter allows excessive data exposure through API access
threat.desc:
General threat description

API calls that access parameters without proper authorization checks or rate limiting could expose sensitive data to external threats.
Threat agents/Attack vectors

External attackers exploiting unsecured API endpoints.
Impacts

Exposure of sensitive credentials or configuration data, leading to service disruption or data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios

An API endpoint retrieves parameters from AWS Parameter Store without properly verifying user permissions, exposing sensitive data to unauthorized users.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1021: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with. A web application is expected to place restrictions on whether it is allowed to be rendered within frames, iframes, objects, embed or applet elements. Without the restrictions, users can be tricked into interacting with the application when they were not intending to.

weakness.name: CWE-287

countermeasure.name: Implement frame busting techniques
countermeasure.desc:
Frame busting is a technique used to prevent a website from being displayed within a frame or iframe of another site. This is crucial to thwart clickjacking attacks, where an attacker might use a frame to overlay deceptive elements over your UI, misleading users into performing unintended actions.

Use the X-Frame-Options HTTP Header

  • Implement the X-Frame-Options HTTP header in your web server's configuration or within your application's response headers.
  • Set this header to DENY to prevent any domain from framing your content.
  • Alternatively, use SAMEORIGIN if you need to allow framing of your content by the same domain.
  • Example for Apache server in .htaccess: Header always set X-Frame-Options "SAMEORIGIN"

Leverage Content Security Policy (CSP)

  • Enhance security by implementing the Content Security Policy header with the frame-ancestors directive.
  • Specify which domains are allowed to frame your siteâ€™s content. To disallow all framing, you can set it to 'none'.
  • Example CSP implementation: Header set Content-Security-Policy "frame-ancestors 'self';"

Employ Frame Busting Scripts

  • While headers are your first line of defense, add a JavaScript frame-busting script for additional protection.
  • Add the following script to your HTML documents to ensure they cannot be framed: 

if (top !== window) {
 top.location = window.location;
}

Regularly Update and Test

  • Regularly update your security configurations to cope with evolving threats.
  • Test your implementation across different browsers and devices to ensure that your site cannot be framed maliciously.

Additional Considerations:

  • Always validate your CSP and frame busting implementations using tools like browsersâ€™ developer tools to ensure they are working as expected.
  • Keep informed about new security practices and potential bypasses to frame busting techniques.

By following these steps, you can significantly enhance the security of your application's user interface against framing attacks, providing a safer environment for your users.

reference.name: OWASP Clickjacking Defense Cheat Sheet

standard.ref: Cross Site Scripting Prevention Cheat Sheet
DOM based XSS Prevention Cheat Sheet
Server Side Request Forgery Prevention Cheat Sheet
Unvalidated Redirects and Forwards Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Implement input validation and sanitization
countermeasure.desc:
Input validation and sanitization are crucial for preventing various forms of attacks, such as SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and command injection. Validation involves verifying whether the input meets the expected format and is within allowable limits. Sanitization involves cleaning the input to ensure that it is safe to handle.

Validate Input Strictly

  • Define the allowed types, patterns, and ranges for all user inputs based on your application's requirements.
  • Use regular expressions to enforce patterns such as email addresses, phone numbers, or user IDs.
  • Reject any input that does not strictly conform to these criteria.
  • Example in Python for an email input: 

import re
def validate_email(email):
   if not re.match(r"[^@]+@[^@]+\.[^@]+", email):
       raise ValueError("Invalid email format")


Sanitize Inputs Before Processing

  • Sanitize inputs by removing or encoding potentially harmful characters, especially when the input is incorporated into web pages or database queries.
  • Utilize libraries or frameworks that automatically handle sanitization, like OWASP Java Encoder for Java applications, or context-aware escaping functions in template engines.
  • Example using Python for web output:

from html import escape
def sanitize_html(input_string):
   return escape(input_string)
 

Use Parameterized Queries for Database Access

  • Avoid SQL injection by using parameterized queries or prepared statements instead of concatenating strings to form SQL commands.
  • Example using Python with SQLite:

import sqlite3
connection = sqlite3.connect('example.db')
cursor = connection.cursor()
cursor.execute("INSERT INTO Users (username) VALUES (?)", (username,))
connection.commit()
connection.close()
 

Apply Security Controls Framework-Wide

  • Ensure that validation and sanitization are consistently applied across all parts of the application that accept user input.
  • Consider using security-focused libraries and frameworks that encourage or enforce good security practices.

Test and Monitor

  • Regularly test your input validation and sanitization measures with both automated tools and manual testing to uncover any potential bypasses or flaws.
  • Monitor application logs for unusual activities that might indicate attempts to exploit input validation weaknesses.

Additional Considerations:

  • Keep abreast of the latest security advisories and updates related to the libraries and frameworks you use.
  • Educate developers about the importance of input validation and sanitization through code reviews and security training sessions.

Implementing thorough input validation and sanitization as described will help protect your application from common vulnerabilities and attacks, ensuring a more secure environment for your users and your data.

reference.name: OWASP Enterprise Security API (ESAPI)

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting
countermeasure.desc:
Rate limiting is crucial for protecting your application from abuse, such as denial-of-service attacks, brute force login attempts, and other types of misuse that could overwhelm your system. It involves restricting the number of requests a user can make to a particular endpoint within a specified time frame.

Define Rate Limits Based on Use Case

  • Assess the typical usage patterns of your application to establish reasonable limits.
  • Set different rate limits for different types of endpoints; for example, more sensitive actions like password changes might have stricter limits compared to more benign actions like viewing content.

Choose a Rate Limiting Strategy

  • Fixed window: Use a consistent time window (e.g., per minute, per hour) and allow a maximum number of requests in that window.
  • Sliding window log: Implement a more flexible approach where the window slides with the incoming requests, providing a smoother limit.
  • Token bucket: Allow bursts of requests but limit the overall rate over time.
  • Leaky bucket: Process requests at a steady rate and buffer bursts to prevent system overload.

Implement Rate Limiting Mechanism

  • Utilize middleware in web frameworks that support rate limiting. For example, for Node.js applications using Express, you can use libraries like express-rate-limit.
  • Example implementation in Express.js:

const rateLimit = require("express-rate-limit");

const limiter = rateLimit({
 windowMs: 15 * 60 * 1000, // 15 minutes
 max: 100, // limit each IP to 100 requests per windowMs
});

// Apply to all requests
app.use(limiter);
 

Store Rate Limiting Data

  • Decide on a storage solution for rate limiting counters, such as Redis, which can handle expiration and distribution efficiently.
  • Ensure that your storage choice can scale and perform under high load, which is critical for high-traffic applications.

Communicate Limits to Users

  • Include headers in HTTP responses to inform users of their current rate limit status, such as X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, and X-RateLimit-Reset.
  • Implement clear messaging on your frontend to alert users when they are approaching or have exceeded their rate limit.

Monitor and Adjust Limits

  • Regularly review the effectiveness of your rate limits. Adjust them based on new usage patterns or feedback from legitimate users who might be impacted.
  • Monitor logs for patterns indicating systematic abuse, and adjust your strategy as needed.

Additional Considerations:

  • Consider implementing IP whitelisting and blacklisting to more finely control access based on the user's behavior history.
  • Be mindful of implementing rate limiting in a way that doesnâ€™t inadvertently block or degrade service for legitimate users, particularly those coming from shared IP addresses like those in corporate or educational environments.

Implementing rate limiting as outlined will help ensure that your application can handle traffic efficiently and safely, protecting both the system and its users from abuse.

reference.name: OWASP REST Security Cheat Sheet

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1035 - Limit Access to Resource Over Network

countermeasure.name: Implement visual cues and indicators
countermeasure.desc:
Visual cues and indicators enhance the usability and security of your application by providing feedback or warnings to users about their interactions or system states. These can include changes in button colors when active, spinner icons during loading phases, or warning messages for potentially insecure actions.

Design Clear and Intuitive Cues

  • Develop a consistent visual language that aligns with your application's design guidelines.
  • Use color, shape, animation, and positioning strategically to draw attention without overwhelming the user.
  • Example: Use a red color for warnings, green for successful actions, and yellow for caution.

Implement Feedback for Interactive Elements

  • Provide immediate feedback for user actions. For example, change the appearance of a button when hovered or clicked.
  • Use animations to indicate loading or processing states, which helps users understand that the application is active and responsive.
  • Example CSS for a button:

.button {
 background-color: #4CAF50; /* Green */
 border: none;
 color: white;
 padding: 15px 32px;
 text-align: center;
 text-decoration: none;
 display: inline-block;
 font-size: 16px;
 margin: 4px 2px;
 cursor: pointer;
 transition: background-color 0.3s ease;
}

.button:hover {
 background-color: #45a049;
}
 

Use Indicators for System Status

  • Indicate system or process statuses clearly, such as online/offline modes, connection issues, or security states.
  • Implement a visual indicator for secure sessions (e.g., a padlock icon when a connection is secured with SSL/TLS).
  • Example in HTML: <div id="status" class="status-offline">Offline</div>

Provide Contextual Help and Tooltips

  • Integrate tooltips or help icons next to complex features or inputs that require explanation.
  • Ensure tooltips are accessible on all devices, including mobile and those used by individuals with disabilities.
  • Example HTML for a tooltip: <a href="#" data-tooltip="Enter your email here. We do not share your email with anyone.">Email:</a>

Test for Clarity and Effectiveness

  • Conduct usability testing to gauge the effectiveness of your visual cues and indicators.
  • Gather user feedback to refine and adjust the visual elements to ensure they are understood and appreciated by users.

Ensure Accessibility

  • Make sure that all visual cues are accessible, including to those with visual impairments or color blindness.
  • Use text labels or ARIA labels in addition to color-based cues.

Additional Considerations:

  • Keep in mind that not all users interpret colors and icons the same way; cultural differences can influence user perception.
  • Regularly update visual elements to stay in line with modern UI/UX trends and standards.

By implementing visual cues and indicators as described, you can significantly enhance user interaction and security awareness within your application, providing a more engaging and safe experience.

reference.name: OWASP UI Redressing (Clickjacking) Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Use content security policy (CSP)
countermeasure.desc:
A Content Security Policy (CSP) is a security layer used to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. CSP works by specifying which sources the browser should allow to load resources from, thereby preventing malicious scripts from executing if they violate the specified policy.

Define Your CSP Strategy

  • Decide what kind of resources you want to restrict, such as scripts, stylesheets, images, frames, and more.
  • Identify the domains that your application should accept as valid sources for these resources.

Implement CSP via HTTP Headers

  • Configure your web server to send the Content-Security-Policy HTTP header.
  • Start with a restrictive policy and gradually allow specific domains and resources as needed.
  • Example strict CSP header: Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; script-src 'self' https://apis.example.com; connect-src 'self'; img-src 'self' https://images.example.com;

Test CSP Implementation

  • Deploy the CSP in a testing environment.
  • Use tools like Google Chrome's Developer Tools to monitor CSP violations, which will be reported in the console.
  • Adjust the policy based on the results, allowing additional sources as necessary or tightening restrictions if feasible.

Use Nonce or Hash Values for Inline Scripts and Styles

  • If you must use inline scripts or styles, incorporate nonces (a random number that can only be used once) or hashes to whitelist specific scripts or styles.
  • Modify your CSP policy to include the nonce or hash: script-src 'nonce-2726c7f26c' 'strict-dynamic'; style-src 'sha256-x+y+z/';
  • Update your HTML to use the nonce or correct hash values:

<script nonce="2726c7f26c">
 console.log('This script runs because it matches the nonce in the CSP header.');
</script>


Handle CSP Violation Reports

  • Consider implementing a CSP report-uri directive to receive reports of policy violations.
  • Analyze violation data to improve policy enforcement and adjust your CSP settings accordingly.
  • Example of adding a report-uri: Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; report-uri /csp-violation-report-endpoint;

Regularly Review and Update Your CSP

  • Regularly review the effectiveness of your CSP and update it as your web application evolves or as new threats emerge.
  • Stay informed about CSP best practices and updates in web standards.

Additional Considerations:

  • Be cautious with the use of the 'unsafe-inline' and 'unsafe-eval' directives as they can weaken your CSP significantly.
  • Educate your development team about the importance of adhering to the CSP, especially when adding new resources or third-party services to your application.

By implementing a CSP, you significantly enhance your application's security posture against common web vulnerabilities, helping to ensure that your content is not misused or maliciously exploited.

reference.name: MDN Web Docs - Content Security Policy

countermeasure.name: Use load balancing and scaling
countermeasure.desc:
Load balancing is the process of distributing network or application traffic across multiple servers to ensure no single server bears too much demand. This enhances the responsiveness and availability of applications. Scaling, on the other hand, involves adjusting the number of resourcesâ€”servers, instances, or containersâ€”to meet varying load levels, which can be done manually or automatically.

Choose the Right Type of Load Balancer

  • Identify the type of load balancer that suits your needs: hardware-based, software-based, or cloud-native.
  • Consider using Application Load Balancers for HTTP/HTTPS traffic or Network Load Balancers for TCP/UDP/SCTP traffic if you are in a cloud environment.

Implement Load Balancing

  • Configure a load balancer in front of your server pool. This can be done via hardware devices, software solutions, or services provided by cloud providers.
  • Set up health checks to ensure traffic is only sent to servers that are online and ready to handle requests.
  • Example setup using AWS Elastic Load Balancing: 

Create an Application Load Balancer, define the listening port, and attach it to a target group associated with your EC2 instances.
 

Implement Scaling Policies

  • Decide between manual scaling (where you adjust resources as needed) and auto-scaling (where adjustments are made automatically based on traffic).
  • Set up auto-scaling using cloud services or platform-specific tools to handle increases or decreases in load dynamically.
  • Example using AWS Auto Scaling: 

Define auto-scaling groups and policies based on CPU utilization or other performance metrics to automatically add or remove EC2 instances.
 

Test Your Implementation

  • Simulate traffic loads to validate that the load balancer correctly distributes traffic across your server environment.
  • Test scaling policies by artificially generating spikes in traffic and observing the response.

Monitor and Optimize

  • Continuously monitor the performance of your load balancers and the health of servers.
  • Use analytics and monitoring tools to track load patterns and scaling events, adjusting policies and configurations as necessary.

Ensure Security

  • Implement security measures such as SSL/TLS termination at the load balancer if it supports it, to offload processing from backend servers.
  • Regularly update and patch your load balancers and ensure that security configurations are enforced.

Document and Maintain Your Setup

  • Keep detailed documentation of your load balancing configurations and scaling policies.
  • Regularly review and update your setup in response to infrastructure changes, application updates, or shifts in traffic patterns.

Additional Considerations:

  • Load balancing and scaling not only enhance performance and availability but also contribute to fault tolerance. By distributing traffic and resources, you mitigate the impact of individual server failures.
  • Be aware of the costs associated with scaling, especially in cloud environments where costs can vary widely based on the number and type of resources utilized.

By effectively implementing load balancing and scaling strategies, you ensure that your application can handle varying loads efficiently while maintaining high availability and performance.

reference.name: OWASP Denial of Service Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Use multi-factor authentication
countermeasure.desc:
Multi-factor authentication enhances security by requiring users to provide two or more verification factors to gain access to a resource, such as an application, online account, or a VPN. This significantly reduces the risk of unauthorized access resulting from compromised credentials.

Determine Appropriate Factors

  • Select the types of authentication factors you will use. Common factors include:
    1. Something you know (e.g., password or PIN)
    2. Something you have (e.g., security token, smartphone app, or smart card)
    3. Something you are (e.g., biometrics like fingerprints or facial recognition)

Choose an MFA Solution

  • Evaluate and choose an MFA solution that fits your security requirements and budget. Consider solutions from vendors like Google Authenticator, Authy, Microsoft Authenticator, or hardware-based tokens like YubiKey.
  • Ensure the solution integrates well with your existing security infrastructure and user management systems.

Implement MFA

  • Integrate MFA into your authentication process. This often involves modifying login workflows to include additional authentication steps.
  • Example setup for an online service:

Upon entering their username and password, users are prompted to enter a code generated by their authentication app or sent via SMS.
 

Enforce MFA Policies

  • Define and enforce policies around the use of MFA. Consider making MFA mandatory for accessing sensitive systems or data.
  • Set up policies to handle lost or unavailable authentication factors, such as backup codes or administrative resets.

Educate Users

  • Provide training and documentation to users on why MFA is important and how to use the chosen MFA method.
  • Offer support for users who might have difficulties setting up or using MFA.

Monitor and Review

  • Regularly review the effectiveness of your MFA implementation. Look for any security incidents that may indicate bypasses or failures in your MFA setup.
  • Monitor user compliance with MFA policies and address any areas where adherence may be lacking.

Maintain Security Standards

  • Keep the MFA solution updated to defend against new vulnerabilities.
  • Regularly evaluate new authentication methods and technologies to enhance security as needed.

Additional Considerations:

  • Be mindful of the user experience. Implementing MFA should balance security with usability. Overly complicated MFA processes can lead to user frustration or bypass attempts.
  • Consider the implications of relying on SMS-based authentication, as it can be less secure than other methods due to vulnerabilities in mobile networks.

By implementing MFA, you add a critical layer of security that protects against the most common threats to user accounts, particularly credential theft. This makes unauthorized access significantly more difficult, safeguarding your systems and data effectively.

reference.name: NIST Special Publication 800-63B

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)
PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

countermeasure.name: Use x-frame-options header
countermeasure.desc:
The X-Frame-Options HTTP header is used to control whether a web browser should be allowed to render a page in a <frame>, <iframe>, <embed>, or <object> tag. This header is an effective measure to prevent clickjacking attacks where an attacker tricks a user into clicking on something different than what the user perceives, thereby hijacking the user's intended action.

Choose an Appropriate Directive There are three directives you can set for the X-Frame-Options header:

  • DENY: No rendering within a frame, no matter the origin.
  • SAMEORIGIN: Only allows pages from the same origin as the page itself to be framed.
  • ALLOW-FROM uri: Allows pages to be framed but only by the specified uri.

Implement the Header in Your Web Server Depending on your server, you will need to add configuration to send the X-Frame-Options header. Here are configurations for common web servers:

  • Apache: Edit your .htaccess, httpd.conf, or vhost.conf file: Header always set X-Frame-Options "SAMEORIGIN"
  • Nginx: Add to your server configuration: add_header X-Frame-Options "SAMEORIGIN";
  • IIS: Add to your web.config:

<system.webServer>
 <httpProtocol>
   <customHeaders>
     <add name="X-Frame-Options" value="SAMEORIGIN" />
   </customHeaders>
 </httpProtocol>
</system.webServer>
 

Test Your Configuration

  • Deploy the changes to a test environment.
  • Use tools such as web security testing tools or browser developer tools to ensure the X-Frame-Options header is being sent correctly.
  • Test embedding your site in frames from other origins to ensure the policy works as expected.

Monitor and Adjust as Necessary

  • After deploying the X-Frame-Options header, monitor your application's logs and user feedback to detect any issues or unintended interactions caused by the policy.
  • Adjust the policy as needed based on the operational and security needs of your application.

Consider Modern Alternatives While the X-Frame-Options header is supported widely, consider implementing Content Security Policy (CSP) with the frame-ancestors directive for more granular control over framing. CSP is considered a more modern and flexible approach: Content-Security-Policy: frame-ancestors 'self' https://trusteddomain.com;
Additional Considerations:

  • Ensure all web servers and environments in your infrastructure are configured consistently to use the X-Frame-Options header.
  • Educate your development team about the risks of clickjacking and the role of HTTP headers like X-Frame-Options in mitigating these risks.

By using the X-Frame-Options header correctly, you strengthen your web applicationâ€™s defenses against clickjacking attacks, providing a safer and more secure environment for your users.

reference.name: OWASP Clickjacking Defense Cheat Sheet

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: An attacker can perform denial-of-service (DoS) attacks on the user interface
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

A Denial-of-Service (DoS) attack on the User Interface (UI) targets the elements that users interact with to disrupt service and render the application unusable. Unlike traditional network-level DoS attacks that saturate the server with traffic, UI-focused DoS attacks aim to overload or break the interface components, thereby preventing legitimate user actions and interactions. These attacks may involve flooding the UI with excessive requests, manipulating UI components to cause failures, or exploiting vulnerabilities that cause the application to hang or crash.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

The primary agents of UI DoS attacks are often external attackers who may not require authenticated access to the application. Attack vectors can include:

  • Automated scripts that repeatedly trigger heavy UI processes.
  • Exploitation of flaws in client-side scripts like JavaScript to initiate intensive operations that freeze the UI.
  • Abusive use of legitimate functions, such as overly complex search queries or rapid sequence actions that the UI isnâ€™t designed to handle efficiently.

Impacts:

The impacts of a UI DoS attack are significant and can include:

  • Degradation of application performance leading to slow response times or total unavailability.
  • Reduced productivity and potential revenue loss if users cannot complete transactions or access services.
  • Erosion of trust in the application's reliability, which might deter users from returning.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker develops a script that automates the process of opening and closing an advanced options menu in the application's UI rapidly and continuously. This menu requires significant processing power to render. The script triggers this function faster than the application can handle, leading to a buffer overflow error that crashes the application for all users.

Scenario 2: An e-commerce websiteâ€™s product search feature is exploited where the attacker sends complex, nested search queries at a high frequency. Each query is designed to be computationally expensive, invoking deep database searches and extensive result rendering efforts. The server remains operational, but the UI becomes irresponsive to legitimate user queries due to the load, effectively denying service.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: An attacker can perform clickjacking attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Clickjacking, also known as a "UI redress attack," involves tricking a user into clicking on something different from what the user perceives, effectively hijacking the user's intended actions. This attack leverages embedded components, such as an invisible or disguised iframe, overlaid on legitimate UI elements. The attacker manipulates visibility and positioning to coax the user into performing actions like clicking on a button or link that triggers unintended operations. These operations could range from granting permissions and accessing camera or microphone to liking social media content or initiating financial transactions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

Clickjacking primarily exploits vulnerabilities in the way web applications handle UI layering and user input. Threat agents include:

  • Malicious website operators who embed the target application within an iframe on their site with deceptive overlays.
  • Adversaries distributing links through emails, social media, or other platforms that lead to such malicious pages.

Impacts:

The impacts of clickjacking can vary widely based on the nature of the unintended action but typically include:

  • Unauthorized actions performed on behalf of the user, leading to data theft, account compromise, or financial loss.
  • Compromised privacy, if permissions are manipulated to access hardware like cameras or microphones.
  • Erosion of user trust in the security of the application.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: A user visits a seemingly benign news article shared on social media. Unknown to the user, the page contains an invisible iframe overlaying a popular social networking site where the user is still logged in. The article prompts the user to click to "reveal" content, but the click actually submits a "change password" request on the social network, with the new password controlled by the attacker.

Scenario 2: An attacker sets up a fake game website where users are encouraged to click on various parts of the screen to interact with the game. However, each click is actually on an invisible overlay that causes the user to unknowingly purchase items on an e-commerce platform, using a session the user had previously authenticated but not logged out of.

threat.name: An attacker can perform UI redressing attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

UI redressing is a type of attack where an attacker manipulates the visual presentation of an application's user interface to deceive the user into performing unintended actions. This attack is closely related to clickjacking but can involve additional elements such as misleading visual cues, overlaying deceptive content, or rearranging UI components to induce errors. The goal is often to obtain sensitive information, trigger unauthorized commands, or mislead users into interacting with malicious elements.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

UI redressing can be executed by external attackers who may craft malicious web pages or applications that load the target UI elements in a deceptive manner. Common attack vectors include:

  • Embedding the legitimate application within a custom, deceptive frame or overlay.
  • Manipulating CSS and HTML to alter the appearance or layout of legitimate UI components.
  • Using floating elements or other graphical tricks to cover or modify the appearance of the real interface.

Impacts:

The impacts of UI redressing attacks include:

  • Unauthorized transactions or operations performed without the user's genuine consent.
  • Compromise of sensitive information, such as login credentials or personal data.
  • Damage to the userâ€™s trust in the applicationâ€™s integrity and security, potentially affecting the reputation and reliability of the service provider.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker designs a webpage that looks like a popular video streaming service's login page. The attacker's page is actually an overlay on the legitimate service. When users enter their credentials, they believe they are logging into the streaming service, but their username and password are sent to the attacker.

Scenario 2: A user visits a custom-crafted website that appears to offer a benign survey. However, the survey's "Submit" button is strategically placed over a digital wallet's "Send Money" button, which is loaded invisibly in the background via an iframe. As the user attempts to submit the survey, they unintentionally authorize a payment to an account controlled by the attacker.

These scenarios exploit the visual trust users have in familiar interfaces, turning ordinary interactions into harmful actions without the userâ€™s knowledge.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1192 - Spearphishing Link||ATLAS - AML.T0052 - Phishing

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: An attacker can perform cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks occur when an attacker injects malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users. These scripts can execute in the context of the user's session, allowing the attacker to bypass normal access controls and directly manipulate the user interface or steal sensitive information such as session tokens, cookies, or personal data. XSS attacks typically exploit vulnerabilities in web applications that fail to properly sanitize input data before including it in output.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

Threat agents include anyone with the ability to manipulate input fields where script injection is possible. Attack vectors are typically through:

  • User inputs that are improperly sanitized, allowing script injection into dynamically generated web pages.
  • Malicious payloads delivered via URL parameters, form fields, or even via manipulated documents that the user interacts with, such as PDFs or emails.

Impacts:

The impacts of XSS attacks can be severe, including:

  • Session hijacking, where attackers gain control of a user's active session.
  • Defacement of the website, which can damage the organizationâ€™s reputation.
  • Phishing attacks orchestrated through the trusted site by displaying deceptive content.
  • Installation of malware or initiating unauthorized transactions or actions on behalf of the user.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker places a malicious script in a comment on a public forum that lacks proper input sanitization. When other users view the comment, the script executes within their browser, stealing their session cookies and sending them back to the attacker. The attacker then uses these cookies to hijack the usersâ€™ sessions and gain unauthorized access to their accounts.

Scenario 2: A user receives an email with a link that appears to lead to a legitimate survey hosted by their bank. The link actually redirects to a version of the bank's login page that includes an XSS payload in the URL. When the user logs in, the script executes and captures their keystrokes, sending their username and password to the attacker.

In both scenarios, the attacker exploits the trust users have in the application's security, using the application itself as a vector to deliver harmful scripts.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1659 - Content Injection||ATLAS - AML.T0018.001 - Modify AI Model Architecture

component.name: Client
component.desc: End user accessing the application frontend.

weakness.name: CWE-1021
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1021: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with. A web application is expected to place restrictions on whether it is allowed to be rendered within frames, iframes, objects, embed or applet elements. Without the restrictions, users can be tricked into interacting with the application when they were not intending to.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

countermeasure.name: Avoid unsafe DOM manipulation and isolate untrusted scripts
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of a web client application, it is crucial to avoid the use of methods such as innerHTML and document.write for inserting dynamic content, as they can expose the application to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. Instead, implement JavaScript sandboxing techniques to restrict script execution and limit the impact of potential malicious code. Follow these steps to effectively apply these practices:

  1. Avoid using innerHTML and document.write:
    • Whenever possible, use textContent or innerText when inserting user-generated content into the DOM. These methods escape HTML, preventing the execution of any injected scripts.
    • For generating dynamic HTML content, use DOM manipulation methods like createElement, appendChild, or insertAdjacentElement.
  2. Implement Strict Content Security Policy (CSP):
    • Define a CSP policy that limits where resources can be loaded from and prevent inline scripts from executing without specific nonce or hash attributes.
    • Update the server configuration to include a secure CSP header. For example, configure your web server to send a header like: Content-Security-Policy: script-src 'self'.
  3. Utilize JavaScript sandboxing:
    • Use iframe elements with the sandbox attribute to run potentially untrusted scripts in a restricted execution environment.
    • Define sandbox rules to disable certain capabilities such as form submissions or plugin usage by including restrictions like sandox="allow-same-origin allow-scripts", while continuously adjusting these based on real application needs and security assessments.
  4. Apply libraries and frameworks for secure data binding:
    • Consider utilizing frontend frameworks such as React, Angular, or Vue.js, which inherently handle safe data binding and abstraction layers to reduce direct DOM manipulation.
    • These libraries offer protection features and methods against XSS due to their managed templating systems.
  5. Regularly update and audit code:
    • Ensure that your codebase and dependencies are regularly updated to mitigate known vulnerabilities.
    • Perform security audits and code reviews focusing on areas where user input impacts DOM manipulation.

By following these guidelines, you can mitigate risks associated with unsafe DOM manipulation and script execution, enhancing the overall security posture of your web client application.

References

  • MDN Web Docs - innerHTML Security Considerations
  • Content Security Policy (CSP) Reference
  • React Documentation - Introducing JSX
  • Angular Guide - Security

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity
SI-6 Security and Privacy Function Verification
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

countermeasure.name: Detect and block UI redressing attempts
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the web client by preventing clickjacking attacks, follow these JavaScript-based frame-busting implementation steps:

  1. Function Initialization: Ensure the JavaScript function is executed as soon as the document is loaded. This can be done by placing the script at the end of the HTML body or attaching it to the window's onLoad event as shown in the example.
    1. window.onLoad = function() {    // Detect if the page is in an iframe    if (window.top !== window.self) {        window.top.location = window.self.location;    } }
  2. Frame-busting Script Logic: Implement a simple check within your JavaScript to detect whether the current webpage is being loaded within an iframe. This can be achieved by checking if window.top is equal to window.self.
  3. Redirection: If the webpage is inside an iframe, redirect the top frame to the current page's location. This effectively pulls the website out of the iframe and prevents the site from being embedded.
  4. Deploy and Test: After embedding this script in your application, ensure it correctly prevents your page from being displayed in any iframe. Conduct thorough testing to verify that normal usage is unaffected while iframe attempts are appropriately blocked.
  5. Detecting Overlays: Use client-side scripts to detect unexpected overlays. This involves monitoring the DOM for unauthorized inserted elements.

For this, include event listeners on dynamic DOM changes using MutationObservers, and if any suspicious elements are detected, take actions, such as denying access to specific features or alerting the user.

const observer = new MutationObserver((mutations) => {    mutations.forEach((mutation) => {        // Logic to detect and respond to unauthorized overlay or UI changes        if (/* some condition to identify a suspicious DOM node */) {            alert('Suspicious activity detected!');            // Optionally take further action, like removing the element        }    }); }); observer.observe(document.body, { childList: true, subtree: true });

  1. Start Observing DOM: Use the MutationObserver API to watch changes in the DOM structure. Observe body elements to catch any suspicious insertions or changes.
  2. Define Conditions: Specify what constitutes an unexpected overlay based on your applicationâ€™s expected behavior and UI state. For instance, look for fullscreen unauthorized dialog boxes.
  3. Handle Detected Anomalies: If a breakpoint is detected, you can either alert the user directly or log out activities for further review while limiting available actions.

References

  • MDN Web Docs: Window.self
  • MDN Web Docs: MutationObserver
  • OWASP: Clickjacking Defense

countermeasure.name: Ensure secure communication and validate external resources
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Web Client, it is crucial to enforce HTTPS with strong TLS (Transport Layer Security) configurations, ensuring the encryption and integrity of data transmitted between the client and server.

  1. Configure HTTPS:
    1. Obtain an SSL/TLS certificate from a trusted Certificate Authority (CA).
    2. Configure your web server (such as Apache, Nginx, or IIS) to use the obtained certificate. Refer to your server documentation for specific instructions.
    3. Ensure that all content, including images, scripts, and stylesheets, are served over HTTPS to avoid mixed content issues.
    4. Set up automatic HTTPS redirection by implementing HTTP to HTTPS redirects, ensuring that all traffic to your web client is encrypted.
  2. Implement Strong TLS Configurations:
    1. Disable outdated and vulnerable protocols (e.g., TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1) and enforce the use of TLS 1.2 or higher.
    2. Configure your web server to use strong cipher suites, removing support for weak ones. Ensure that Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) is enabled to provide additional security.
    3. Regularly review and update your server configurations to adhere to the latest security guidelines and best practices.
  3. Disable HTTP/2 Prioritization Attack Risk:
    1. Ensure HTTP/2 prioritization is implemented correctly, or disable it if not needed, to prevent attack vectors that exploit the feature.
  4. Validate External Resources with Subresource Integrity (SRI):
    1. Edit the HTML of your web client to include the integrity attribute on any <script> or <link> tags that load content from external sources.
    2. Generate the integrity hash value for the resource. Use a tool like SRI Hash Generator by pasting the URL of the external resource or the content itself.
    3. Include the generated hash within the integrity attribute of your HTML tags, specifying a hash algorithm such as SHA-384 or SHA-512.
    4. Regularly audit and update the SRI hashes whenever external resources are updated to ensure proper validation continues.

References

  • Let's Encrypt - Getting Started
  • Mozilla Developer Network - HTTP Strict Transport Security
  • OWASP Transport Layer Protection Cheat Sheet
  • Mozilla Security Server Side TLS Guide
  • Mozilla Developer Network - Subresource Integrity

countermeasure.name: Prevent storage of sensitive data on the client
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of a web client, it's crucial to handle sensitive information such as authentication tokens, API keys, and personally identifiable information (PII) with care. Here's a step-by-step guide to ensuring these data types are protected:

  1. Assessment of Current Storage Practices:

    • Audit current methods for storing sensitive information within your web client.
    • Identify any instances where information is stored in local storage, session storage, or client-side databases.

  2. Implement Secure Storage Practices:

    • Avoid storing sensitive values like authentication tokens or API keys in session storage or local storage whenever possible to reduce the risk of exposure.
    • If unavoidable, use secure alternatives such as storing temporary session data on server-side sessions.

  3. Encryption of Data:

    • If local storage is imperative, leverage encryption to secure your data. Use the Web Crypto API to encrypt data before storing it on the client-side.
    • Generate a cryptographic key using the Web Crypto API's `generateKey` method.
    • Use the `subtle.encrypt` method of the Web Crypto API to encrypt sensitive data before storage.
    • Ensure you store the keys securely and consider using server-side sessions or a secure cookie-based mechanism for sensitive token and key exchange.

  4. Information Minimization:

    • Only store data that is absolutely necessary for client operation, reducing the amount of sensitive information available to potential attackers.

  5. Regular Security Reviews:

    • Conduct regular security reviews and penetration tests to ensure data storage practices remain secure against emerging vulnerabilities and threats.

References

  • MDN Web Crypto API Documentation
  • OWASP Top Ten - Sensitive Data Exposure
  • Google Developers - Store Credentials Securely
