usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Policy bypass
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

An attacker finds a loophole in the access control rules or the manager's enforcement logic. This allows them to perform a specific, unauthorized action, such as accessing a forbidden model, that the policy was designed to prevent, without needing to escalate their overall privilege level.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: A malicious or curious user (insider or compromised account) probing the system's policy logic for weaknesses.
  • Vectors: The system has conflicting access rules (e.g., a "deny" for a user and an "allow" for a group they are in), and it resolves the conflict in an insecure way; an attacker bypasses a name-based rule by using a different character encoding or case for the model's name; a policy denies access based on a model's name, but an attacker finds its unique ID and accesses it directly via an API call that the rule does not cover.
  • Impacts: Unauthorized access to or execution of sensitive, proprietary AI models, leading to intellectual property theft; the integrity of the access control system is undermined, as its rules are proven to be circumventable; and a failure to meet the strict access control requirements of data protection and AI regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A policy denies the "contractor" role access to models tagged "Internal," but another policy allows the "project-X" group to access an internal model. A contractor gets added to "project-X" and can now bypass the intended restriction.
  • An access control rule is written to deny access to the sensitive model named "PROD_FINANCE_MODEL". An attacker discovers the check is case-sensitive and successfully accesses the model by requesting "prod_finance_model".
  • A policy blocks access to a model by its name. An attacker, however, discovers the model's unique numerical ID from a separate source. They make a direct API call using the ID, which the name-based policy does not check, and successfully access the model.

threat.name: Privilege misconfiguration and drift
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A user's permissions become excessive, either through an initial setup error (misconfiguration) or by gradually accumulating unnecessary rights as they change roles over time (drift). This violation of the principle of least privilege creates standing, high-level privileges that can be abused by an insider or an attacker.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators; a lack of a regular access review process; the natural movement of employees between roles.
  • Vectors: An administrator accidentally assigns a new user to a highly privileged role; an employee moves to a new team and is granted new permissions, but their old, unnecessary permissions are never revoked, causing "privilege creep"; the organization has no process to periodically review and recertify user access, allowing stale permissions to accumulate across the user base.
  • Impacts: A large number of users have standing privileges that far exceed their job requirements, increasing the insider threat surface; the compromise of a single, long-term employee's account can become a critical incident due to their accumulated privileges; and a systematic failure of the principle of least privilege, violating the access control requirements of major security and privacy regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An employee has been with a company for ten years, changing roles multiple times. Their old access rights were never revoked. An attacker compromises this one account and discovers they now have access to a wide range of sensitive models and data from across the entire company.
  • During a hurried onboarding, a new junior employee is accidentally assigned the permissions of a senior architect. The junior employee, exploring the system, discovers they have the ability to delete or modify any production AI model in the registry.
  • An internal audit reveals that dozens of employees who left a specific high-stakes project over a year ago still have full access to its highly sensitive and proprietary AI models, a clear sign of unmanaged privilege drift.

threat.name: Escalation of privilege
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

An attacker exploits a flaw in the access control logic to elevate their permissions. This allows a low-privilege user to gain the rights of a privileged user, enabling them to access, modify, or execute models they are not authorized to use.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: A malicious low-privilege user, either an insider or an attacker who has compromised an account.
  • Vectors: An authorized user modifies an API request to ask for an unauthorized model ID, and the system fails to re-validate their permissions for the new target (IDOR); a user discovers and abuses an unprotected API endpoint to add themselves to a high-privilege administrative group; an attacker exploits a vulnerability to directly modify the access control policy itself, granting their account elevated rights.
  • Impacts: Unauthorized access to sensitive or proprietary AI models, leading to intellectual property theft; the ability to tamper with, delete, or replace production models, compromising the integrity of dependent applications; and a complete administrative takeover of the model governance system.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A user is authorized to access model-A. They notice the API call is /api/models/model-A. They change the call to /api/models/model-B, which is a highly sensitive model. A flaw in the access control manager grants the request, allowing them to access the unauthorized model.
  • A junior developer, exploring internal APIs, finds an unprotected endpoint for managing user groups. They use this to add their own account to the "ML Administrators" group. The access control manager now grants them full administrative privileges over the entire model registry.
  • The access control policy is stored in a file that is compromised by an attacker. The attacker edits the policy to add their user ID to the list of administrators. The next time the manager reloads the policy, the attacker's privileges are elevated.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure defaults
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The Model Access Control Manager's default, out-of-the-box configuration is overly permissive. An administrator who installs the system but fails to immediately apply a more restrictive security policy leaves models and their associated data exposed to unauthorized access.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: The software vendor providing the insecure defaults; administrators who fail to harden the system after installation.
  • Vectors: The default system policy is to "allow all," meaning new models are accessible to everyone until an explicit "deny" rule is added; the manager is installed with a default administrator account that has a well-known, documented password; built-in default roles like "Viewer" grant access to all models in the system, rather than none.
  • Impacts: A high risk of widespread, unauthorized access to sensitive models immediately after deployment; a complete administrative takeover of the access control system if default credentials are not changed; and a false sense of security, as administrators may incorrectly assume the default settings are safe.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A new, highly sensitive model is registered in the system. Because the access control manager's default policy is "allow all authenticated users," this secret model is immediately visible to every employee in the company.
  • An administrator installs a new access control manager and forgets the final step of changing the default admin password. An attacker on the internal network scans for the manager's login page and takes full control of the system using the well-known default credentials.
  • A new user is assigned the default "Auditor" role, which is believed to be safe. However, the default configuration for this role grants read access to every model in the registry. The user can now view the company's most secret, proprietary AI models.

customField.value: ATLAS - AML.T0047 - AI-Enabled Product or Service

threat.name: Token and key leakage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive credentials used by or for the Model Access Control Managerâ€”such as its own API keys, service account secrets, or database passwordsâ€”are leaked through insecure code, configuration, or logs. An attacker can use these secrets to bypass the manager or compromise its underlying infrastructure.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators, malicious insiders, or an attacker who has compromised the manager's host environment.
  • Vectors: A password used by the manager to connect to its policy database is hardcoded in a configuration file and committed to Git; the manager is set to a verbose log level and exposes its own credentials in the startup logs; secrets are passed to the manager's process as insecure environment variables, which can be read by an attacker who gains a foothold on the host.
  • Impacts: A complete bypass of the access control system, as an attacker can impersonate it or alter its policies; theft of the entire access control database, including all users, permissions, and rules; and a critical security failure, as the component responsible for enforcing security is itself compromised.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An administrator stores the password for the database that holds the access control policies in a plaintext configuration file. An attacker with read access to the server's filesystem steals this file, connects to the database, and alters the policies to grant themselves admin rights.
  • To troubleshoot an issue, the access control manager's logging level is set to "DEBUG." On startup, it logs its entire configuration, including the client secret it uses to authenticate to the central identity provider. An insider with log access steals this secret.
  • A service account key is passed to the manager's container as an environment variable. An attacker finds a separate vulnerability in the application, executes a command to list all environment variables, and steals the powerful key.

customField.value: ATLAS - AML.T0057 - LLM Data Leakage||ATLAS - AML.TA0013 - Credential Access

threat.name: Unauthorized download of exposed model checkpoints from public repositories
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A failure to correctly apply access policies to the underlying storage repository allows unauthorized actors to directly download proprietary model checkpoints, completely bypassing the Model Access Control Manager and its intended security checks.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Competing companies, malicious actors, data hoarders.
  • Vectors: Using automated scanners to find public cloud buckets, discovering accidentally public repositories on platforms like Hugging Face or GitHub, or exploiting misconfigured IAM roles on model storage.

Impacts

  • Intellectual Property Theft: The entire model, which can be a company's most valuable digital asset, is stolen with a simple download.
  • Enabling Further Attacks: Attackers can analyze the stolen model to discover vulnerabilities, infer information about the training data, or craft adversarial examples.
  • Complete Loss of Exclusivity: A proprietary model intended for a paid service or internal use becomes a public commodity, resulting in direct revenue loss and erosion of competitive advantage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • A developer uploads a new model to a Hugging Face repository but forgets to set its status to "private," allowing a rival company to download it within hours.
  • An automated script misconfigures the permissions on an S3 bucket used for storing hourly model checkpoints, making every version of the model publicly readable and downloadable.
  • An engineer trying to share a model with a collaborator sets the hosting folder's permissions to "public" for convenience and forgets to revoke them, leading to the model being indexed by search tools.

customField.value: ATLAS - AML.T0002 - Acquire Public AI Artifacts

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Audit and logging gaps
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The Model Access Control Manager fails to generate a complete and tamper-evident audit trail of all access decisions and administrative actions. This blindness allows an attacker or malicious insider to cover their tracks and prevents any effective forensic investigation into unauthorized activity.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders or external attackers; negligent administrators who misconfigure logging.
  • Vectors: The system is configured to only log successful access attempts but not denials, making brute-force attacks invisible; audit logs are stored in a mutable format (like a standard database), allowing a malicious administrator to delete or alter records to hide their actions; the system fails to log administrative changes, such as a modification to an access policy, allowing an insider to create a temporary backdoor without a trace.
  • Impacts: A complete inability to perform forensic analysis after a security incident; attackers can probe for weaknesses or exfiltrate data without fear of detection; and a direct violation of the strict auditing requirements of major AI and data protection regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker launches a credential-spraying attack, making thousands of failed access attempts against the model API. Because the access control manager was configured to not log failed events, no alerts are triggered and the security team is unaware the system is under attack.
  • A malicious administrator temporarily grants themselves access to a highly sensitive model, steals it, and then revokes the permission. Afterwards, they connect to the logging database and delete the specific records of their activity, successfully covering their tracks.
  • An insider wants to leak a new model. They briefly change an access policy to grant a public-facing service account permission to read the model. After the model is leaked, they revert the policy change. An investigation is inconclusive because the policy modification itself was not logged as a security event.
